instruction: How does the developed automatic star spectrum classification method compare to traditional methods in terms of handling large-scale spectral surveys and addressing data set imbalance?
Output:
The developed automatic star spectrum classification method, based on a semi-supervised mode of one-dimensional convolutional neural network (CNN) and one-dimensional generative adversarial network (GAN), offers several advantages compared to traditional methods in handling large-scale spectral surveys and addressing data set imbalance.

1. Handling large-scale spectral surveys: With the implementation of more and more large-scale spectral surveys, a significant amount of star spectral data is generated. The traditional spectral classification and processing methods face challenges in dealing with such a large amount of data. The automatic star spectrum classification method utilizes one-dimensional CNN to classify the spectra of six types of stars (excluding O-type) with an average classification accuracy of 98.08%. This approach enables efficient and accurate classification of a large number of star spectra.

2. Addressing data set imbalance: The LAMOST DR7 (v2.0 version) spectral data set released in 2021 contains millions of star spectra, but the number of O-type spectra is only 129, resulting in a serious data set imbalance. Traditional machine learning classification methods struggle to achieve good results with such imbalanced data sets. The developed method employs a one-dimensional GAN network to address this issue.
